title: What happens if you guess? - Leigh Nataro

multiple-choice.question: What area of mathematics is used in making predictions in sports, such as determining the odds for who will win the Super Bowl?
What is the fundamental counting principle used to determine the number of possible outcomes?

options.label: A
options.text: If there are A possible outcomes for one event, and B possible outcomes for another event, then there are A minus B ways to pair the outcomes.

options.label: B
options.text: If there are A possible outcomes for one event, and B possible outcomes for another event, then there are A times B ways to pair the outcomes.

options.label: C
options.text: If there are A possible outcomes for one event, and B possible outcomes for another event, then there are A plus B ways to pair the outcomes.

options.label: D
options.text: If there are A possible outcomes for one event, and B possible outcomes for another event, then there are A divided by B ways to pair the outcomes.

multiple-choice.question: What is the probability of getting a perfect score by randomly guessing on a 10-question true/false quiz?
What is the most common score if you and all your friends were to always randomly guess at every question on a 10-question true/false quiz?

options.label: D
options.text: A mix of all the above

multiple-choice.question: What is the probability of getting all 20 questions correct by randomly guessing on a 20-question multiple-choice test with 5 possible answers for each question?
What is the average number of questions you would get right by guessing on a 10-question true/false quiz?
What is the probability of getting a question right by guessing on a multiple-choice test with 5 possible answers for each question?
What is the number of possible outcomes for a 10-question true/false quiz, assuming there are two possible answers for each question?
What is the expected score if you and all your friends were to always randomly guess at every question on a 20-question multiple-choice test with 5 possible answers for each question?

options.label: D
options.text: A mix of all the above

multiple-choice.question: What is the value of 5 to the 20th power?
What is the probability of getting all 20 questions correct by randomly guessing on a 20-question multiple-choice test with 5 possible answers for each question?
What is the expected score if you and all your friends were to always randomly guess at every question on a 10-question true/false quiz?

options.label: D
options.text: A mix of all the above

multiple-choice.question: What is the probability of getting a question right by guessing on a multiple-choice test with 5 possible answers for each question?
What is the number of possible outcomes for a 10-question true/false quiz, assuming there are two possible answers for each question?
What area of mathematics is used in helping to set auto insurance rates?
What is the main benefit of authentic narrative in journalism?

options.label: A
options.text: It makes the story more technical and factual.

options.label: B
options.text: It adds a personal touch, but is not essential.

options.label: C
options.text: It connects people and makes the personal universal.

options.label: D
options.text: It makes the story more complex and confusing.

multiple-choice.question: What is the "trifecta of sourcing" in journalism?

options.label: A
options.text: A single source that provides all the information.

options.label: B
options.text: Three types of sources: official, overview, and unofficial.

options.label: C
options.text: A process of verifying facts and data.

multiple-choice.question: What type of sources provide the "why" behind a story?
What is the role of unofficial sources in journalism?

options.label: B
options.text: To give an overview of the situation.

options.label: C
options.text: To provide the individual's insight and perspective.

options.label: D
options.text: To verify the information provided by official sources.

multiple-choice.question: What is the key to asking surprising questions that yield compelling information?

options.label: A
options.text: By asking the same questions repeatedly.

options.label: B
options.text: By asking the questions that are already known.

options.label: C
options.text: By asking questions that yield unexpected answers.

options.label: D
options.text: By asking questions that are too complicated.

multiple-choice.question: What is the significance of anecdotes in journalism?

options.label: A
options.text: They are unnecessary and can be skipped.

options.label: B
options.text: They add flavor to the story but are not essential.

options.label: C
options.text: They breathe life into a story and make it more engaging.

options.label: D
options.text: They are only used in feature stories.

multiple-choice.question: What is the primary role of narrative in journalism?

options.label: A
options.text: To present facts and data quickly and efficiently.

options.label: B
options.text: To connect people and make the personal universal.

multiple-choice.question: In what situations is it essential to convey information quickly?

options.label: A
options.text: When the situation is not urgent and can be discussed later.

options.label: B
options.text: When the situation is urgent and action is required.

options.label: C
options.text: When the audience is not interested in the information.

options.label: D
options.text: When the information is not important.

multiple-choice.question: What does the "slow dance of information" in journalism refer to?

options.label: A
options.text: A process of verifying facts and presenting information quickly.

options.label: B
options.text: A process of presenting information in a clear and concise manner.

options.label: C
options.text: A process of presenting information in a slow and detailed manner, allowing for a deeper understanding of the story.

multiple-choice.question: What is the ultimate goal of journalism?

options.label: C
options.text: To connect people and make the personal universal.

multiple-choice.question: What are the three components of the "trifecta of sourcing" in journalism?

options.label: A
options.text: Official sources, overview sources, and unofficial sources.

options.label: B
options.text: Official sources, unofficial sources, and fact-checkers.

options.label: C
options.text: Overview sources, unofficial sources, and experts.

multiple-choice.question: How do journalists use the "trifecta of sourcing" to gather information?

options.label: A
options.text: By relying on a single type of source.

options.label: B
options.text: By using all three types of sources to gather a comprehensive understanding of the story.

options.label: C
options.text: By verifying information through multiple sources.

multiple-choice.question: What is the importance of asking surprising questions in journalism?

options.label: A
options.text: It helps to gather information quickly.

options.label: B
options.text: It allows journalists to present information in a clear and concise manner.

options.label: C
options.text: It helps to gather unique and compelling information that adds depth to a story.

options.label: D
options.text: It is not essential in journalism.

multiple-choice.question: How do anecdotes contribute to a story in journalism?

options.label: A
options.text: They add facts and data to the story.

options.label: B
options.text: They provide a detailed analysis of the situation.

options.label: C
options.text: They breathe life into a story and make it more engaging.

options.label: D
options.text: They are unnecessary and can be skipped.

multiple-choice.question: What is the significance of the "slow dance of information" in journalism?

options.label: A
options.text: It allows journalists to present information quickly and efficiently.

options.label: B
options.text: It enables journalists to gather information through a comprehensive and detailed process.

options.label: C
options.text: It is not essential in journalism.

options.label: D
options.text: It is only used only in feature stories.

title: How fiction can change reality - Jessica Wise

multiple-choice.question: Who said, "There is no frigate like a book to take us lands away..."?
What happens to us when we step onto the shore after being carried away by a story?

options.label: A
options.text: We retrace the footsteps of the authors or characters we followed

options.label: B
options.text: We walk a mile in their shoes

options.label: C
options.text: We forget the story we just read

multiple-choice.question: According to scholars, what shape culture and influence our ideas about life?
Which novel, written by Samuel Richardson, challenged a slew of traditions and caused quite a ruckus?
What characteristic does Darwin's theory of evolution privilege?

options.label: A
options.text: Intelligence, swiftness, and adaptability to change

multiple-choice.question: According to recent studies, what might be wrong about our sense of being a hero?

options.label: C
options.text: We're not members of a shared quest

multiple-choice.question: Why should we read and enjoy the classics?

options.label: C
options.text: Because they can teach us about the past and help us understand the present

options.label: D
options.text: Because they're not relevant to our lives

multiple-choice.question: What might "Hunger Games" lead us to think about?
What might "Uglies" reflect?

options.label: A
options.text: The dangers of pursuing a perfect body

multiple-choice.question: What is the final question asked in the transcript?

options.label: A
options.text: What story will you try on next?

options.label: B
options.text: What is the meaning of life?

options.label: C
options.text: What is the purpose of reading?

options.label: D
options.text: What is the importance of imagination?

multiple-choice.question: What is the main reason logarithms are used to determine the pH of water samples that cause one to have red eyes after swimming?

options.label: A
options.text: To calculate the concentration of hydrogen ions

options.label: B
options.text: To determine the pH of the water samples using the formula pH equals negative log base 10 of the hydrogen ion concentration

options.label: C
options.text: To measure the concentration of oxygen ions

options.label: D
options.text: To measure the temperature of the water

multiple-choice.question: What is the formula to calculate the pH of water samples?

options.label: A
options.text: pH equals log base 10 of the hydrogen ion concentration

options.label: B
options.text: pH equals negative log base 10 of the hydrogen ion concentration

options.label: C
options.text: pH equals log base 10 of the oxygen ion concentration

options.label: D
options.text: pH equals negative log base 10 of the oxygen ion concentration

multiple-choice.question: What is the value of log base 10 of 10,000?
What is the main application of logarithms in chemistry?

options.label: A
options.text: To calculate the pH of water samples

options.label: B
options.text: To determine the concentration of hydrogen ions

options.label: C
options.text: To measure the temperature of a substance

options.label: D
options.text: To calculate the density of a substance

multiple-choice.question: If the pH of a water sample is 7.4, what can be concluded about its H+ concentration?
A person's eyes turn red after swimming in a pool with a pH of 8.4. What can be concluded about the H+ concentration of the pool?
If a calculator is used to find the pH of a water sample with an H+ concentration of 0.0000000398, what will be the result?
What is the relationship between the pH of a substance and its H+ concentration?

options.label: C
options.text: pH equals negative log base 10 of the H+ concentration

options.label: D
options.text: pH equals log base 10 of the H+ concentration

multiple-choice.question: A person wants to find the pH of a water sample with an H+ concentration of 0.00000000398. What is the best way to do this?

options.label: B
options.text: Use a calculator to find the negative log base 10 of the H+ concentration

options.label: C
options.text: Use a thermometer to measure the temperature of the water

options.label: D
options.text: Use a hydrometer to measure the density of the water

multiple-choice.question: What is the main advantage of using logarithms in chemistry?

options.label: C
options.text: They can be used to find the pH of water samples

options.label: D
options.text: They can be used to measure the temperature of a substance

title: The history of keeping time - Karen Mensing

multiple-choice.question: What is the earliest known form of telling time?
What is the primary limitation of sundials as a time-keeping device?

options.label: A
options.text: They are too complex to use

options.label: B
options.text: They require the sun to shine

multiple-choice.question: What device was commonly used on board ships to estimate the passage of time?
What is the basis for scientific time today?

options.label: A
options.text: A continuous count of seconds based on atomic clocks all around the world

options.label: C
options.text: The vibration of a quartz crystal

multiple-choice.question: Why does it matter that we keep track of time?

options.label: A
options.text: Time regulates our daily lives and makes it possible to accurately communicate with people all over the world

options.label: B
options.text: Time only regulates our daily lives

options.label: C
options.text: Time only makes it possible to communicate with people all over the world

multiple-choice.question: What is the purpose of a time zone?

options.label: C
options.text: To measure the passage of time

options.label: D
options.text: To estimate the passage of time

multiple-choice.question: What is the approximate time difference between New York and Boston?
How many time zones are there on land?
What is the approximate time difference between Boston and Australia?
What would be the challenges without a time system?

options.label: A
options.text: Farming, social structures, communication, and business
